trans-unit.source: Overview
Philosophy
Markdown is intended to be as easy-to-read and easy-to-write as is feasible.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown is intended to be as easy-to-read and easy-to-write as is feasible.

target.mrk: Markdown is intended to be as easy-to-read and easy-to-write as is feasible.

trans-unit.source: Readability, however, is emphasized above all else. A Markdown-formatted document should be publishable as-is, as plain text, without looking like it's been marked up with tags or formatting instructions. While Markdown's syntax has been influenced by several existing text-to-HTML filters -- including [Setext] [1], [atx] [2], [Textile] [3], [reStructuredText] [4], [Grutatext] [5], and [EtText] [6] -- the single biggest source of inspiration for Markdown's syntax is the format of plain text email.

seg-source.mrk: Readability, however, is emphasized above all else.
document should be publishable as-is, as plain text, without looking
like it's been marked up with tags or formatting instructions.
Markdown's syntax has been influenced by several existing text-to-HTML
[Grutatext] [5], and [EtText] [6] -- the single biggest source of
inspiration for Markdown's syntax is the format of plain text email.

target.mrk: Readability, however, is emphasized above all else.
document should be publishable as-is, as plain text, without looking
like it's been marked up with tags or formatting instructions.
Markdown's syntax has been influenced by several existing text-to-HTML
[Grutatext] [5], and [EtText] [6] -- the single biggest source of
inspiration for Markdown's syntax is the format of plain text email.

trans-unit.source: To this end, Markdown's syntax is comprised entirely of punctuation characters, which punctuation characters have been carefully chosen so as to look like what they mean. E.g., asterisks around a word actually look like \*emphasis\*. Markdown lists look like, well, lists. Even blockquotes look like quoted passages of text, assuming you've ever used email.

trans-unit.source: Inline HTML
Markdown's syntax is intended for one purpose: to be used as a format for *writing* for the web.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown's syntax is intended for one purpose: to be used as a

target.mrk: Markdown's syntax is intended for one purpose: to be used as a

trans-unit.source: Markdown is not a replacement for HTML, or even close to it. Its syntax is very small, corresponding only to a very small subset of HTML tags. The idea is *not* to create a syntax that makes it easier to insert HTML tags. In my opinion, HTML tags are already easy to insert. The idea for Markdown is to make it easy to read, write, and edit prose. HTML is a *publishing* format; Markdown is a *writing* format. Thus, Markdown's formatting syntax only addresses issues that can be conveyed in plain text.

can be conveyed in plain text.

trans-unit.source: For any markup that is not covered by Markdown's syntax, you simply use HTML itself. There's no need to preface it or delimit it to indicate that you're switching from Markdown to HTML; you just use the tags.

trans-unit.source:
The only restrictions are that block-level HTML elements -- e.g. `
`, ``, `
`, `
`, etc. -- must be separated from surrounding
content by blank lines, and the start and end tags of the block should
not be indented with tabs or spaces. Markdown is smart enough not
to add extra (unwanted) `
` tags around HTML block-level tags.

` tags around HTML block-level tags.

Note that Markdown formatting syntax is not processed within block-level HTML tags. E.g., you can't use Markdown-style `*emphasis*` inside an HTML block.

trans-unit.source: Span-level HTML tags -- e.g. ``, ``, or `` -- can be used anywhere in a Markdown paragraph, list item, or header. If you want, you can even use HTML tags instead of Markdown formatting; e.g. if you'd prefer to use HTML `` or `` tags instead of Markdown's link or image syntax, go right ahead.

used anywhere in a Markdown paragraph, list item, or header.

you'd prefer to use HTML `` or `` tags instead of Markdown's
link or image syntax, go right ahead.

trans-unit.source: Automatic Escaping for Special Characters

In HTML, there are two characters that demand special treatment: `<` and `&`. Left angle brackets are used to start tags; ampersands are used to denote HTML entities. If you want to use them as literal characters, you must escape them as entities, e.g. `<`, and `&`.

seg-source.mrk: In HTML, there are two characters that demand special treatment: `<`
Left angle brackets are used to start tags; ampersands are
If you want to use them as literal
characters, you must escape them as entities, e.g. `<`, and

target.mrk: In HTML, there are two characters that demand special treatment: `<`
Left angle brackets are used to start tags; ampersands are
If you want to use them as literal
characters, you must escape them as entities, e.g. `<`, and

trans-unit.source: Ampersands in particular are bedeviling for web writers. If you want to write about 'AT&T', you need to write '`AT&T`'. You even need to escape ampersands within URLs. Thus, if you want to link to:

seg-source.mrk: Ampersands in particular are bedeviling for web writers.
write about 'AT&T', you need to write '`AT&T`'.
Thus, if you want to link to:

target.mrk: Ampersands in particular are bedeviling for web writers.
write about 'AT&T', you need to write '`AT&T`'.
Thus, if you want to link to:

trans-unit.source: http://images.google.com/images?num=30&q=larry+bird
you need to encode the URL as:

seg-source.mrk: you need to encode the URL as:

target.mrk: you need to encode the URL as:

trans-unit.source: http://images.google.com/images?num=30&q=larry+bird
in your anchor tag `href` attribute. Needless to say, this is easy to forget, and is probably the single most common source of HTML validation errors in otherwise well-marked-up web sites.

seg-source.mrk: Needless to say, this is easy to
forget, and is probably the single most common source of HTML validation
errors in otherwise well-marked-up web sites.

target.mrk: Needless to say, this is easy to
forget, and is probably the single most common source of HTML validation
errors in otherwise well-marked-up web sites.

trans-unit.source: Markdown allows you to use these characters naturally, taking care of all the necessary escaping for you. If you use an ampersand as part of an HTML entity, it remains unchanged; otherwise it will be translated into `&`.

all the necessary escaping for you.
If you use an ampersand as part of
an HTML entity, it remains unchanged; otherwise it will be translated

target.mrk: Markdown allows you to use these characters naturally, taking care of
all the necessary escaping for you.
If you use an ampersand as part of
an HTML entity, it remains unchanged; otherwise it will be translated

trans-unit.source: So, if you want to include a copyright symbol in your article, you can write:

and Markdown will leave it alone. But if you write:

AT&T
Similarly, because Markdown supports [inline HTML](#html), if you use angle brackets as delimiters for HTML tags, Markdown will treat them as such. But if you write:

angle brackets as delimiters for HTML tags, Markdown will treat them as

target.mrk: Similarly, because Markdown supports [inline HTML](#html), if you use
angle brackets as delimiters for HTML tags, Markdown will treat them as

trans-unit.source: Markdown will translate it to:

However, inside Markdown code spans and blocks, angle brackets and ampersands are *always* encoded automatically. This makes it easy to use Markdown to write about HTML code. (As opposed to raw HTML, which is a terrible format for writing about HTML syntax, because every single `<` and `&` in your example code needs to be escaped.)

trans-unit.source: Block Elements
Paragraphs and Line Breaks

A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated by one or more blank lines. (A blank line is any line that looks like a blank line -- a line containing nothing but spaces or tabs is considered blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be indented with spaces or tabs.

seg-source.mrk: A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated
by one or more blank lines.
(A blank line is any line that looks like a
blank line -- a line containing nothing but spaces or tabs is considered
blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be indented with spaces or tabs.

target.mrk: A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated
by one or more blank lines.
(A blank line is any line that looks like a
blank line -- a line containing nothing but spaces or tabs is considered
blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be indented with spaces or tabs.

trans-unit.source:
The implication of the "one or more consecutive lines of text" rule is that Markdown supports "hard-wrapped" text paragraphs. This differs significantly from most other text-to-HTML formatters (including Movable Type's "Convert Line Breaks" option) which translate every line break character in a paragraph into a `
` tag.

seg-source.mrk: The implication of the "one or more consecutive lines of text" rule is
significantly from most other text-to-HTML formatters (including Movable
Type's "Convert Line Breaks" option) which translate every line break

character in a paragraph into a `
` tag.

target.mrk: The implication of the "one or more consecutive lines of text" rule is
significantly from most other text-to-HTML formatters (including Movable
Type's "Convert Line Breaks" option) which translate every line break

character in a paragraph into a `
` tag.

trans-unit.source:
When you *do* want to insert a `
` break tag using Markdown, you end a line with two or more spaces, then type return.

When you *do* want to insert a `
` break tag using Markdown, you
end a line with two or more spaces, then type return.

target.mrk:
When you *do* want to insert a `
` break tag using Markdown, you
end a line with two or more spaces, then type return.

trans-unit.source:
Yes, this takes a tad more effort to create a `
`, but a simplistic "every line break is a `
`" rule wouldn't work for Markdown. Markdown's email-style [blockquoting][bq] and multi-paragraph [list items][l] work best -- and look better -- when you format them with hard breaks.

Yes, this takes a tad more effort to create a `
`, but a simplistic

"every line break is a `
`" rule wouldn't work for Markdown.
work best -- and look better -- when you format them with hard breaks.

`, but a simplistic

`" rule wouldn't work for Markdown.

trans-unit.source: Headers
Markdown supports two styles of headers, [Setext] [1] and [atx] [2].

seg-source.mrk: Markdown supports two styles of headers, [Setext] [1] and [atx] [2].

target.mrk: Markdown supports two styles of headers, [Setext] [1] and [atx] [2].

trans-unit.source: Setext-style headers are "underlined" using equal signs (for first-level headers) and dashes (for second-level headers). For example:

seg-source.mrk: Setext-style headers are "underlined" using equal signs (for first-level

target.mrk: Setext-style headers are "underlined" using equal signs (for first-level

trans-unit.source: Any number of underlining `=`'s or `-`'s will work.

seg-source.mrk: Any number of underlining `=`'s or `-`'s will work.

target.mrk: Any number of underlining `=`'s or `-`'s will work.

trans-unit.source: Atx-style headers use 1-6 hash characters at the start of the line, corresponding to header levels 1-6. For example:

seg-source.mrk: Atx-style headers use 1-6 hash characters at the start of the line,

target.mrk: Atx-style headers use 1-6 hash characters at the start of the line,

trans-unit.source:
# This is an H1
## This is an H2
###### This is an H6

Optionally, you may "close" atx-style headers. This is purely cosmetic -- you can use this if you think it looks better. The closing hashes don't even need to match the number of hashes used to open the header. (The number of opening hashes determines the header level.) :

seg-source.mrk: cosmetic -- you can use this if you think it looks better.
closing hashes don't even need to match the number of hashes

target.mrk: cosmetic -- you can use this if you think it looks better.
closing hashes don't even need to match the number of hashes

trans-unit.source:
# This is an H1 #
## This is an H2 ##
### This is an H3 ######
Blockquotes

Markdown uses email-style `>` characters for blockquoting. If you're familiar with quoting passages of text in an email message, then you know how to create a blockquote in Markdown. It looks best if you hard wrap the text and put a `>` before every line:

seg-source.mrk: Markdown uses email-style `>` characters for blockquoting.
familiar with quoting passages of text in an email message, then you
know how to create a blockquote in Markdown.
It looks best if you hard
wrap the text and put a `>` before every line:

target.mrk: Markdown uses email-style `>` characters for blockquoting.
familiar with quoting passages of text in an email message, then you
know how to create a blockquote in Markdown.
It looks best if you hard
wrap the text and put a `>` before every line:

trans-unit.source: > This is a blockquote with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, > consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus. > Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae, risus. > > Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit. Suspendisse > id sem consectetuer libero luctus adipiscing.

trans-unit.source: Blockquotes can be nested (i.e. a blockquote-in-a-blockquote) by adding additional levels of `>`:

target.mrk: Blockquotes can be nested (i.e. a blockquote-in-a-blockquote) by

This is the second list item.

trans-unit.source: Any decent text editor should make email-style quoting easy. For example, with BBEdit, you can make a selection and choose Increase Quote Level from the Text menu.

example, with BBEdit, you can make a selection and choose Increase
Quote Level from the Text menu.

trans-unit.source: Lists
Markdown supports ordered (numbered) and unordered (bulleted) lists.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown supports ordered (numbered) and unordered (bulleted) lists.

target.mrk: Markdown supports ordered (numbered) and unordered (bulleted) lists.

trans-unit.source: Unordered lists use asterisks, pluses, and hyphens -- interchangably -- as list markers:

seg-source.mrk: Unordered lists use asterisks, pluses, and hyphens -- interchangably

target.mrk: Unordered lists use asterisks, pluses, and hyphens -- interchangably

trans-unit.source: * Red * Green * Blue
is equivalent to:
+ Red + Green + Blue
and:
- Red - Green - Blue
Ordered lists use numbers followed by periods:

seg-source.mrk: Ordered lists use numbers followed by periods:

target.mrk: Ordered lists use numbers followed by periods:

trans-unit.source: 1. Bird 2. McHale 3. Parish
It's important to note that the actual numbers you use to mark the list have no effect on the HTML output Markdown produces. The HTML Markdown produces from the above list is:

seg-source.mrk: It's important to note that the actual numbers you use to mark the
list have no effect on the HTML output Markdown produces.
Markdown produces from the above list is:

target.mrk: It's important to note that the actual numbers you use to mark the
list have no effect on the HTML output Markdown produces.
Markdown produces from the above list is:

trans-unit.source:
1. Bird
  2. McHale
  3. Parish
If you instead wrote the list in Markdown like this:

seg-source.mrk: If you instead wrote the list in Markdown like this:

target.mrk: If you instead wrote the list in Markdown like this:

trans-unit.source: 1. Bird 1. McHale 1. Parish
or even:
3. Bird 1. McHale 8. Parish

you'd get the exact same HTML output. The point is, if you want to, you can use ordinal numbers in your ordered Markdown lists, so that the numbers in your source match the numbers in your published HTML. But if you want to be lazy, you don't have to.

seg-source.mrk: you'd get the exact same HTML output.
The point is, if you want to,
you can use ordinal numbers in your ordered Markdown lists, so that
the numbers in your source match the numbers in your published HTML.
But if you want to be lazy, you don't have to.

target.mrk: you'd get the exact same HTML output.
The point is, if you want to,
you can use ordinal numbers in your ordered Markdown lists, so that
the numbers in your source match the numbers in your published HTML.
But if you want to be lazy, you don't have to.

trans-unit.source: If you do use lazy list numbering, however, you should still start the list with the number 1. At some point in the future, Markdown may support starting ordered lists at an arbitrary number.

At some point in the future, Markdown may support
starting ordered lists at an arbitrary number.

At some point in the future, Markdown may support
starting ordered lists at an arbitrary number.

List markers must be followed by one or more spaces

List markers must be followed by one or more spaces

will turn into:

  • Magic
But this:

* Magic
will turn into:

List items may consist of multiple paragraphs. Each subsequent paragraph in a list item must be indented by either 4 spaces or one tab:

paragraph in a list item must be indented by either 4 spaces

trans-unit.source:
1. This is a list item with two paragraphs. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aliquam hendrerit mi posuere lectus.
Vestibulum enim wisi, viverra nec, fringilla in, laoreet vitae, risus. Donec sit amet nisl. Aliquam semper ipsum sit amet velit.

Code Blocks

Pre-formatted code blocks are used for writing about programming or markup source code. Rather than forming normal paragraphs, the lines of a code block are interpreted literally. Markdown wraps a code block in both `<pre>` and `<code>` tags.

seg-source.mrk: Pre-formatted code blocks are used for writing about programming or
Rather than forming normal paragraphs, the lines
of a code block are interpreted literally.

target.mrk: Pre-formatted code blocks are used for writing about programming or
Rather than forming normal paragraphs, the lines
of a code block are interpreted literally.

trans-unit.source: To produce a code block in Markdown, simply indent every line of the block by at least 4 spaces or 1 tab. For example, given this input:

seg-source.mrk: To produce a code block in Markdown, simply indent every line of the
block by at least 4 spaces or 1 tab.

target.mrk: To produce a code block in Markdown, simply indent every line of the
block by at least 4 spaces or 1 tab.

This is a normal paragraph:
This is a code block.
Markdown will generate:

This is a normal paragraph:

This is a code block.
One level of indentation -- 4 spaces or 1 tab -- is removed from each line of the code block. For example, this:

Here is an example of AppleScript:

    beep
end tell
A code block continues until it reaches a line that is not indented (or the end of the article).

target.mrk: A code block continues until it reaches a line that is not indented

trans-unit.source: Within a code block, ampersands (`&`) and angle brackets (`<` and `>`) are automatically converted into HTML entities. This makes it very easy to include example HTML source code using Markdown -- just paste it and indent it, and Markdown will handle the hassle of encoding the ampersands and angle brackets. For example, this:

are automatically converted into HTML entities.

easy to include example HTML source code using Markdown -- just paste
it and indent it, and Markdown will handle the hassle of encoding the

trans-unit.source: © 2004 Foo Corporation
will turn into:

<div class="footer">
    © 2004 Foo Corporation
</div>

Regular Markdown syntax is not processed within code blocks. E.g., asterisks are just literal asterisks within a code block. This means it's also easy to use Markdown to write about Markdown's own syntax.

seg-source.mrk: Regular Markdown syntax is not processed within code blocks.
asterisks are just literal asterisks within a code block.
it's also easy to use Markdown to write about Markdown's own syntax.

target.mrk: Regular Markdown syntax is not processed within code blocks.
asterisks are just literal asterisks within a code block.
it's also easy to use Markdown to write about Markdown's own syntax.

trans-unit.source: Horizontal Rules

You can produce a horizontal rule tag (`<hr />`) by placing three or more hyphens, asterisks, or underscores on a line by themselves. If you wish, you may use spaces between the hyphens or asterisks. Each of the following lines will produce a horizontal rule:

more hyphens, asterisks, or underscores on a line by themselves.
wish, you may use spaces between the hyphens or asterisks.

Links
Markdown supports two style of links: *inline* and *reference*.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown supports two style of links: *inline* and *reference*.

target.mrk: Markdown supports two style of links: *inline* and *reference*.

trans-unit.source: In both styles, the link text is delimited by [square brackets].

seg-source.mrk: In both styles, the link text is delimited by [square brackets].

target.mrk: In both styles, the link text is delimited by [square brackets].

trans-unit.source: To create an inline link, use a set of regular parentheses immediately after the link text's closing square bracket. Inside the parentheses, put the URL where you want the link to point, along with an *optional* title for the link, surrounded in quotes. For example:

seg-source.mrk: To create an inline link, use a set of regular parentheses immediately
after the link text's closing square bracket.
put the URL where you want the link to point, along with an *optional*
title for the link, surrounded in quotes.

target.mrk: To create an inline link, use a set of regular parentheses immediately
after the link text's closing square bracket.
put the URL where you want the link to point, along with an *optional*
title for the link, surrounded in quotes.

trans-unit.source:
This is [an example](http://example.com/ "Title") inline link.
[This link](http://example.net/) has no title attribute.
Will produce:

This is an example inline link.

This link has no title attribute.
If you're referring to a local resource on the same server, you can use relative paths:

Reference-style links use a second set of square brackets, inside which you place a label of your choosing to identify the link:

which you place a label of your choosing to identify the link:

target.mrk: Reference-style links use a second set of square brackets, inside
which you place a label of your choosing to identify the link:

trans-unit.source: This is [an example][id] reference-style link.
You can optionally use a space to separate the sets of brackets:

seg-source.mrk: You can optionally use a space to separate the sets of brackets:

target.mrk: You can optionally use a space to separate the sets of brackets:

trans-unit.source: This is [an example] [id] reference-style link.
Then, anywhere in the document, you define your link label like this, on a line by itself:

seg-source.mrk: Then, anywhere in the document, you define your link label like this,

target.mrk: Then, anywhere in the document, you define your link label like this,

trans-unit.source: [id]: http://example.com/ "Optional Title Here"
That is:
Square brackets containing the link identifier (optionally indented from the left margin using up to three spaces);

seg-source.mrk: Square brackets containing the link identifier (optionally
indented from the left margin using up to three spaces);

target.mrk: Square brackets containing the link identifier (optionally
indented from the left margin using up to three spaces);

trans-unit.source: followed by a colon;
followed by one or more spaces (or tabs);

target.mrk: followed by one or more spaces (or tabs);

trans-unit.source: followed by the URL for the link;

seg-source.mrk: followed by the URL for the link;

target.mrk: followed by the URL for the link;

trans-unit.source: optionally followed by a title attribute for the link, enclosed in double or single quotes, or enclosed in parentheses.

seg-source.mrk: optionally followed by a title attribute for the link, enclosed
in double or single quotes, or enclosed in parentheses.

target.mrk: optionally followed by a title attribute for the link, enclosed
in double or single quotes, or enclosed in parentheses.

trans-unit.source: The following three link definitions are equivalent:

seg-source.mrk: The following three link definitions are equivalent:

target.mrk: The following three link definitions are equivalent:

trans-unit.source: [foo]: http://example.com/ "Optional Title Here" [foo]: http://example.com/ 'Optional Title Here' [foo]: http://example.com/ (Optional Title Here)
**Note:** There is a known bug in Markdown.pl 1.0.1 which prevents single quotes from being used to delimit link titles.

single quotes from being used to delimit link titles.

target.mrk: **Note:** There is a known bug in Markdown.pl 1.0.1 which prevents
single quotes from being used to delimit link titles.

trans-unit.source: The link URL may, optionally, be surrounded by angle brackets:

seg-source.mrk: The link URL may, optionally, be surrounded by angle brackets:

target.mrk: The link URL may, optionally, be surrounded by angle brackets:

trans-unit.source: [id]: <http://example.com/> "Optional Title Here"
You can put the title attribute on the next line and use extra spaces or tabs for padding, which tends to look better with longer URLs:

seg-source.mrk: You can put the title attribute on the next line and use extra spaces
or tabs for padding, which tends to look better with longer URLs:

target.mrk: You can put the title attribute on the next line and use extra spaces
or tabs for padding, which tends to look better with longer URLs:

trans-unit.source: [id]: http://example.com/longish/path/to/resource/here "Optional Title Here"
Link definitions are only used for creating links during Markdown processing, and are stripped from your document in the HTML output.

seg-source.mrk: Link definitions are only used for creating links during Markdown
processing, and are stripped from your document in the HTML output.

target.mrk: Link definitions are only used for creating links during Markdown
processing, and are stripped from your document in the HTML output.

trans-unit.source: Link definition names may consist of letters, numbers, spaces, and punctuation -- but they are *not* case sensitive. E.g. these two links:

seg-source.mrk: Link definition names may consist of letters, numbers, spaces, and
punctuation -- but they are *not* case sensitive.

target.mrk: Link definition names may consist of letters, numbers, spaces, and
punctuation -- but they are *not* case sensitive.

trans-unit.source: [link text][a] [link text][A]
are equivalent.

The *implicit link name* shortcut allows you to omit the name of the link, in which case the link text itself is used as the name. Just use an empty set of square brackets -- e.g., to link the word "Google" to the google.com web site, you could simply write:

link, in which case the link text itself is used as the name.

target.mrk: The *implicit link name* shortcut allows you to omit the name of the

Just use an empty set of square brackets -- e.g., to link the word
"Google" to the google.com web site, you could simply write:

trans-unit.source: [Google][]
And then define the link:
[Google]: http://google.com/
Because link names may contain spaces, this shortcut even works for multiple words in the link text:

multiple words in the link text:

target.mrk: Because link names may contain spaces, this shortcut even works for
multiple words in the link text:

trans-unit.source: Visit [Daring Fireball][] for more information.
And then define the link:
[Daring Fireball]: http://daringfireball.net/

Link definitions can be placed anywhere in your Markdown document. I tend to put them immediately after each paragraph in which they're used, but if you want, you can put them all at the end of your document, sort of like footnotes.

trans-unit.source: The point of reference-style links is not that they're easier to write. The point is that with reference-style links, your document source is vastly more readable. Compare the above examples: using reference-style links, the paragraph itself is only 81 characters long; with inline-style links, it's 176 characters; and as raw HTML, it's 234 characters. In the raw HTML, there's more markup than there is text.

trans-unit.source: With Markdown's reference-style links, a source document much more closely resembles the final output, as rendered in a browser. By allowing you to move the markup-related metadata out of the paragraph, you can add links without interrupting the narrative flow of your prose.

closely resembles the final output, as rendered in a browser.

you can add links without interrupting the narrative flow of your

trans-unit.source: Emphasis

Markdown treats asterisks (`*`) and underscores (`_`) as indicators of emphasis. Text wrapped with one `*` or `_` will be wrapped with an HTML `<em>` tag; double `*`'s or `_`'s will be wrapped with an HTML `<strong>` tag. E.g., this input:

HTML `<em>` tag; double `*`'s or `_`'s will be wrapped with an HTML

*single asterisks*

Images
Admittedly, it's fairly difficult to devise a "natural" syntax for placing images into a plain text document format.

seg-source.mrk: Admittedly, it's fairly difficult to devise a "natural" syntax for
placing images into a plain text document format.

target.mrk: Admittedly, it's fairly difficult to devise a "natural" syntax for
placing images into a plain text document format.

trans-unit.source: Markdown uses an image syntax that is intended to resemble the syntax for links, allowing for two styles: *inline* and *reference*.

seg-source.mrk: Markdown uses an image syntax that is intended to resemble the syntax
for links, allowing for two styles: *inline* and *reference*.

target.mrk: Markdown uses an image syntax that is intended to resemble the syntax
for links, allowing for two styles: *inline* and *reference*.

trans-unit.source: Inline image syntax looks like this:

seg-source.mrk: Inline image syntax looks like this:

target.mrk: Inline image syntax looks like this:

trans-unit.source:
![Alt text](/path/to/img.jpg)
![Alt text](/path/to/img.jpg "Optional title")
That is:
An exclamation mark: `!`;
followed by a set of square brackets, containing the `alt` attribute text for the image;

seg-source.mrk: followed by a set of square brackets, containing the `alt`

target.mrk: followed by a set of square brackets, containing the `alt`

trans-unit.source: followed by a set of parentheses, containing the URL or path to the image, and an optional `title` attribute enclosed in double or single quotes.

As of this writing, Markdown has no syntax for specifying the dimensions of an image; if this is important to you, you can simply use regular HTML `` tags.

trans-unit.source: Miscellaneous
Automatic Links

Markdown supports a shortcut style for creating "automatic" links for URLs and email addresses: simply surround the URL or email address with angle brackets. What this means is that if you want to show the actual text of a URL or email address, and also have it be a clickable link, you can do this:

seg-source.mrk: Markdown supports a shortcut style for creating "automatic" links for URLs and email addresses: simply surround the URL or email address with angle brackets.
What this means is that if you want to show the actual text of a URL or email address, and also have it be a clickable link, you can do this:

target.mrk: Markdown supports a shortcut style for creating "automatic" links for URLs and email addresses: simply surround the URL or email address with angle brackets.
What this means is that if you want to show the actual text of a URL or email address, and also have it be a clickable link, you can do this:

trans-unit.source: <http://example.com/>
Markdown will turn this into:
http://example.com/

Automatic links for email addresses work similarly, except that Markdown will also perform a bit of randomized decimal and hex entity-encoding to help obscure your address from address-harvesting spambots. For example, Markdown will turn this:

seg-source.mrk: Automatic links for email addresses work similarly, except that
Markdown will also perform a bit of randomized decimal and hex
entity-encoding to help obscure your address from address-harvesting
For example, Markdown will turn this:

target.mrk: Automatic links for email addresses work similarly, except that
Markdown will also perform a bit of randomized decimal and hex
entity-encoding to help obscure your address from address-harvesting
For example, Markdown will turn this:

trans-unit.source: <address@example.com>
into something like this:
which will render in a browser as a clickable link to "address@example.com".

seg-source.mrk: which will render in a browser as a clickable link to "address@example.com".

target.mrk: which will render in a browser as a clickable link to "address@example.com".

trans-unit.source: (This sort of entity-encoding trick will indeed fool many, if not most, address-harvesting bots, but it definitely won't fool all of them. It's better than nothing, but an address published in this way will probably eventually start receiving spam.)

will probably eventually start receiving spam.)

will probably eventually start receiving spam.)

trans-unit.source: Backslash Escapes

Markdown allows you to use backslash escapes to generate literal characters which would otherwise have special meaning in Markdown's formatting syntax. For example, if you wanted to surround a word with literal asterisks (instead of an HTML `<em>` tag), you can use backslashes before the asterisks, like this:

seg-source.mrk: Markdown allows you to use backslash escapes to generate literal
characters which would otherwise have special meaning in Markdown's
For example, if you wanted to surround a word
with literal asterisks (instead of an HTML `<em>` tag), you can use
backslashes before the asterisks, like this:

target.mrk: Markdown allows you to use backslash escapes to generate literal
characters which would otherwise have special meaning in Markdown's
For example, if you wanted to surround a word
with literal asterisks (instead of an HTML `<em>` tag), you can use
backslashes before the asterisks, like this:

trans-unit.source: \*literal asterisks\*
Markdown provides backslash escapes for the following characters:

seg-source.mrk: Markdown provides backslash escapes for the following characters:

target.mrk: Markdown provides backslash escapes for the following characters:

trans-unit.source: \ backslash ` backtick * asterisk _ underscore {} curly braces [] square brackets () parentheses # hash mark + plus sign - minus sign (hyphen) . dot ! exclamation mark
